title: Blue Engine
segmentation: Next up, Nick Airmen from Blue Engine who is working to help people in low income public schools get a better chance in it.
Use more academic rigor.
I'll turn it over to Nick.
Welcome, I know it's an academic conference you can clap.
Thank you.
Thank you, thank you, thank you.
Claudia and Jake and Brian for hosting tonight.
It's a really cool way to frame a conference's data for social good.
This is the first time that I've been in a group of such quantitative nerds since my dissertation, which I tried to block out.
But it feels like a bit of a homecoming and so I'm really pleasure really pleased to be here.
I'm the CEO of a nonprofit born in Brooklyn called Blue Engine and we try to accelerate academic rigor in our nation's public high schools.
The question which I don't mean to be rhetorical here at all.
Ever since I finish that dissertation today has always been OK. Fine data for what?
For me it's personal.
I mean this is.
This is my first month on the job, 14 years ago.
First job out of college teaching 27 young people in northeast Washington DC.
4th grade kids nine years old, but you have to understand about them is that they are extraordinarily talented, full of potential high aspirations there.
Batler's survivors.
But what they're not is college graduates.
14 years later, they're 2223 years old and two out of the 27 have a degree.
This is a preventable injustice that Boom Engine was founded to help solve.

By partnering with low income communities, high schools in particular to help accelerate academic rigor and prepare dramatically greater numbers of our young people, no matter where they live for success in higher education.
There's two things I want you guys to take away too.
I know it's late.
This is a crazy dark room, but just remember two things for all the talk that you hear about achievement gaps.
The biggest, most pervasive gap in this country is between what it means to be eligible for college.
And truly ready.
What I mean by that is something.
You know to the tune of 23% of New York City High School graduates some 1.1 million kids in the system here in just 23% after K12 qualify.
To transition without remedial coursework to higher Ed, which compounds nationally.
Only eight of every 100 entering freshmen at low of low income backgrounds finish within six years.
Finished college with degrees.
It's an epidemic of lost talent.

The second thing I want you to realize is that I didn't even know this coming from a sociology background, but there's an alarming consensus in the literature that the strongest predictor of whether kids sink or swim in higher Ed.
Is the level of academic rigor and prep that they get in high school, which is obviously in concert with a lot of social emotional.
Work and and financial barriers.
But the big big big root cause, driver of success and failure is that level of academic prep, so for me it we came now five years ago.
How would we as a room as a country as a sector band together resources differently and use data differently to make sure dramatically greater numbers of kids got this kind of prep?

So our solution is really simple and I don't say that into any sort of silver bullet sense, but we work in partnership with existing public schools, public teachers who are unfortunately working in an outdated way of teaching.
It's one person, 30 students rows of desks, and we know that's going to change through some combination of human capital and technology.
People sign up there called betas, bullingen teaching assistants that come to New York.
They make $14,000 in America or for the year, and they trained to become better educators with us alongside regular classroom teachers.
And they personalize instruction.
They form really deep relationships with young people and we use information that's extracted from those pods.
Layers of information, social, emotional information, cognitive information to try to make better optimized decisions for what the hell happens in classrooms, right?
And so data for what right data for better customization.
Data for better groupings of kids, layering technology on top of human capital so that we have better allocation of time spent in classroom tord's mastery.
Some pods versus others and data for progress to goals.
And so as a result, which are pretty consistently shown if you're a distributional thinker, right, you're seeing like not only baseline to to end of year.
Acceleration of results.
But a compression of the Bell curve so that more who's to say that 90% of kids in a classroom or 100% can't master a skill under the right conditions and so Bell curves in that sense, or sort of?
Unnatural.
Responses in some cases to resource shortages not.
Natural indications of kids own capacity.
So we're looking to change things like this right noise.
To moments of away.
Reckoning
In spark
So that classrooms.
This.
Which belong in the 19th century.

Can be transformed to ones where, for example, principle Kate Callahan Uptown right now in the Bronx, says Blue Engine is moved a huge number of our students in a way that nothing else that we've ever tried has been able to do.
Or in the New York Times last year, games like this are not often seen in education, so it's worth taking note what's happening.
I'll
Well, yeah, three things.
The right data.
The right people.
In the right partners.
So what can you do?
I'll tell you two things.
Take out your phone.
You can donate $5 right now, 4144441444 if everyone does that, you have 70,000 hours of this kind of work, 70,000 hours.
That go to places in the Bronx and Brooklyn and Uptown and downtown, so kids like this can learn in ways that are really responsive to them.
#2, if you want to be more involved in that, we have something called the Board of Engineer since blue engine right.
Haha, so we have folks 60 and climbing all around the world who joined the Board of Engineers and do discrete projects alongside some really talented, hardworking staff.
So if you're interested in either 141444 or email me directly, this is going to go to my inbox.
CEO at blueengine.org.
Thank you so much.
